Please answer TRUE, FALSE or UNKNOWABLE about the text's veracity. In addition write a short summary explaining your answer. If the veracity cannot be determined answer UNKNOWABLE. The first sentence in the response should be TRUE. FALSE. or UNKNOWABLE. eg:UNKNOWABLE.

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

The statement by the Minister for Regional Development, Klára Dostálová, relates to the amendment to the Public Procurement Act approved by the government.

The Minister states that the main reason for submitting the amendment is the effort to speed up procedures and eliminate administrative burdens, which, according to her, is to be adjusted by changing the so-called negotiation procedure without publication. At the request of the government, the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies decided that this proposal will be discussed in a state of legislative emergency, which significantly limits the legislative process. The amendment is currently on the agenda of the meeting from May 26, 2020.

The explanatory memorandum (.pdf, p. 3) of the amendment to the law states:

" The proposed amendment removes administrative obstacles to the award of contracts in negotiated procedures without publication so that negotiated procedures without publication based on Section 63, paragraphs 3 and 5 can be implemented in the shortest possible time. "

And he further comments on the need for adjustments due to the situation caused by the COVID-19 epidemic:

"It is necessary to ensure that the negotiated procedure, which is awarded in extremely urgent circumstances, is as administratively demanding as possible. Given the need to conclude the contract as quickly as possible, it is not appropriate to insist on actions to ensure the qualification of the supplier , convene an evaluation committee, or prevent the conclusion of the contract, as the public interest in the rapid performance of the public contract prevails here."

The key amendment is in Section 67, which regulates the procedure (ibid., p. 1). The following paragraph is added to the current wording:

"(3) In the case of negotiated proceedings without publication pursuant to Section 63(3) and (5), Section 48(7) and (9), Section 73, Section 86 and Section 122 shall not apply."

This point deserves further explanation, as it contains the changes that are to be made. According to paragraphs 3 and 5 of Section 63 , the following applies:

  • “The contracting authority may also use a negotiated procedure without publication if the public contract can only be performed by a particular supplier (…)”
  • “The contracting authority may also use the negotiated procedure without publication if this is necessary as a result of extremely urgent circumstances which the contracting authority could not have foreseen and which it did not cause (…)”

The proposed amendment to the law is therefore intended to allow certain requirements of the law not to be applied in cases of a negotiated procedure without publication, if there is not a large number of suppliers on the market or if there are urgent circumstances for this procedure. The key issue, however, is which requirements of the law will not have to be complied with in these cases.

As a result of the new Section 67, paragraph 3, access to contracts in the negotiated procedure without publication is simplified, for example, for companies that do not have book-entry shares (they do not have to have a clear ownership structure), which is regulated in the current version by Section 48, paragraphs 7 and 9. Companies do not have to submit documents on qualification pursuant to Section 86 , and in the case of legal entities, the contracting authority does not have to ascertain information about its beneficial owner pursuant to Section 122, paragraph 4. At the same time, one of the basic criteria for selecting a supplier pursuant to this Act is abolished - namely, the one that provides the most economically advantageous tender pursuant to Section 122, paragraph 1 .

It is therefore clear that these changes will significantly simplify the process of awarding public contracts through negotiated procedures without publication. However, Transparency International Czech Republic lists a number of consequences that the adoption of the amendment may have. These include, for example, suspicious purchases and potential financial damage to the state caused by providing freedom in the negotiated procedure without publication. The Ministry of Regional Development, in turn, argues for the need to simplify the administratively overly complex procedure.

We assess the statement as true, because the justification of the amendment to the Public Procurement Act and its content clearly show the goal of simplifying and accelerating the award of public contracts in cases falling under tender procedures without publication. However, this fact does not call into question the criticism directed at the discussed amendment. The amendment to the Act may be perceived as potentially dangerous.

SECTION B:

Minister Dostálová made the statement as part of her assessment of the generality of European Union rules in relation to Andrej Babiš's conflict of interest. She stated verbatim: "Prime Minister Babiš is proceeding strictly according to the law. He put his assets into trust funds, he did everything according to the law. The problem is that the European Union regulations are formulated in very general terms. (…) It's terribly vague, really. It's really terribly general. Everything can fit under that." The entire assessment of generality by the minister must therefore be seen in the context of the applicability of the civil law institute of trust funds to avoid conflicts of interest.

Whether a legal regulation is "general" (abstract or concrete in legal theory) is, of course, a largely subjective judgment that we do not assess. We only assess whether the formulation used by the Minister is part of European Union law.

The statement itself is an almost verbatim quote from the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council (.pdf, p. 57, Article 61). Article 61, paragraph (1), literally states that:

"Participants in financial operations within the meaning of Chapter 4 of this Title and other persons, including national authorities at all levels, involved in the implementation of the budget under direct, indirect and shared management, including in the preparation for such action, in audit or control, shall refrain from any action which may bring their interests into conflict with those of the Union. They shall also take appropriate measures to prevent, in the functions within their responsibility, any conflict of interest and to address situations which may objectively be perceived as a conflict of interest."

However, the conflict of interest under paragraph (1) is further slightly specified in paragraph (3) of the same article, which states that: “(…) a conflict of interest occurs if, for family reasons, for emotional ties, for political or national affinity, for economic interest or for other direct or indirect personal interest, the impartial and objective performance of the functions of a participant in financial operations or another person under paragraph 1 is threatened.”

However, European legislation does not specify whether it is possible to "avoid" conflicts of interest using the institution of trust funds (i.e. whether trust funds can be considered "appropriate measures" within the meaning of the article cited above).

We have already described the legal basis of the entire European Commission audit and other regulations in our other justification .

SECTION C:

The entire process investigating Andrej Babiš's potential conflict of interest has been ongoing since 2018, when Transparency International pointed out the potential conflict of interest and also filed a complaint with the European Commission. The first preliminary audit report arrived in the Czech Republic in June 2019.

The audit investigation that preceded the report also affected , among other things, the Ministry for Regional Development (MMR), or rather the National Coordination Body (NOK), whose role (.doc, p. 1) is performed by the MMR. At that time, officials were already in charge of the Czech side's response, so the minister should not have had any influence on it, at least not directly. However, she herself stated : "Now we contradict every sentence on every page. We feel very hurt because a lot of things are not true." We were unable to find in publicly available sources that Minister Dostálová met with EU auditors during the audit or at any time later, or that she was in direct contact with them regarding the report on Andrej Babiš's conflict of interest.

In the case of the response to the second audit report, which was delivered to the Czech Republic in December 2019 and was supposed to contain the final conclusions of the review and also mentioned a conflict of interest, it took longer to write the response. Minister Dostálová herself stated at the time that responses to audit reports are processed by officials. More precisely, she named officials of the National Coordination Body and also their "colleagues from the affected departments" .   As we can learn from information on the iROZHLAS server, this was mainly the Ministry of Industry and Trade and the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs, whose competences include drawing subsidies from the aforementioned structural funds and the Cohesion Fund.

The Minister for Regional Development, especially shortly after the arrival of this second audit report, emphasized (video, 0:48) that the documents are so-called confidential , i.e. in a confidential regime, and that not even ministers have access to them and that it is purely a matter for officials. She allegedly did not read the report herself and is not "interested" in it. However, she had also previously added : "We will definitely want to talk about some things face to face."

The only document currently published is the final audit report (.pdf) of the European Commission. For example, the report states that other entities audited (.pdf, pp. 1–2) are the Ministries of the Environment, Industry and Trade, and Labour and Social Affairs. In addition to the aforementioned ministries, agencies and funds were also audited , such as the Agency for Entrepreneurship and Innovation, the State Environmental Fund of the Czech Republic, the Agency for the Promotion and Entrepreneurship and Investment CzechInvest, the ESI Funds Council, the Common Strategic Framework Funds Council, the National Coordination Body, the Steering and Control Committee, and the City of Prague.

In response to this final report, the Minister stated that the Czech authorities “hold the legal opinion, based on the arguments sent to the European Commission, that there was no breach of regulations” . She also insisted on the existence of two legal interpretations, between which only a court can decide. The Ministry for Regional Development states in its press release that the Czech authorities in their responses to the European Commission “have repeatedly stated that the management and control systems have been set up in the Czech Republic in accordance with EU and national rules governing the issue of conflict of interest and that the Czech Republic maintains this position” .

In conclusion, let us summarize that we were unable to find in publicly available sources whether Klára Dostálová interfered with the officials of the National Coordination Body in formulating their responses to the European Commission, or to what extent this was done. For this reason, we assess the statement as unverifiable.

SECTION D:

In connection with formulating the response to the European Commission's preliminary audit, which announced the existence of a conflict of interest of Prime Minister Babiš, as well as its final version from December 2019 , Minister Dostálová always spoke about the document being processed by officials. Specifically, she mentions officials of the National Coordination Body (NOK), whose function (.doc, p. 1) is performed by the Ministry of Regional Development, and their " colleagues from the affected departments".

In this regard, the iRozhlas server mentions part of the preliminary audit report from June 2019, which states that this concerns " the drawing of subsidies from the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund. This is money that is redistributed primarily by the Ministry of Industry and Trade and the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs."

However, in the final version of the audit report published by the European Commission (.pdf, pp. 1–2) in April this year, we can also read a list of institutions " involved in the process of managing and distributing subsidies" that were the subject of the audit, and which are therefore the above-mentioned " affected departments" . It is these institutions that communicated with the European Commission.

In addition to the supra-ministerial Council for the Common Strategic Framework Funds, the Council for the ESI Funds and the Steering and Coordination Committee, there is the already mentioned National Coordination Body. Three ministries are also listed here: the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, the Ministry of Industry and Trade, the Ministry of the Environment. In addition to them, the report also lists the Agency for Entrepreneurship and Innovation, the State Environmental Fund of the Czech Republic, the Agency for Entrepreneurship and Investment Support CzechInvest and the capital city of Prague.

In total, the audit report lists (.pdf, pp. 1–2) 7 " managing and intermediary institutions" , which include the ministries and agencies just mentioned, and 4 " horizontal institutions" , which include the National Coordination Body and other supra-departmental institutions.

Minister Dostálová is also right that these are not only ministries led by ministers from the ANO movement. The Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs is led by Jana Maláčová from the ČSSD, and the Mayor of Prague is Zdeněk Hřib from the Pirate Party.


SECTION E:

The audit, which was carried out at the Ministry of Regional Development in connection with the monitoring system of European funds, was carried out at the request of the European Commission. The audit was carried out by a team from the Ministry of Finance, which actually revealed irregularities in the contract.

At the time the Ministry of Finance provided the European Commission with the aforementioned audit report, it was headed by Andrej Babiš. At the time, Lukáš Wagenknecht held the position of First Deputy Minister of Finance and was in charge of the audit at the Ministry for Regional Development. Since the Ministry of Finance had officially requested the preparation of the audit by the European Commission, and Minister Babiš thus had information about the audit itself, the accusation against Lukáš Wagenknecht is quite problematic.

The then Minister for Regional Development, Karla Šlechtová, questioned the audit conclusions, however, Lukáš Wagenknecht stated that the audit was carried out in accordance with the law, international audit standards and European Commission guidelines.

Based on an audit report prepared by the Ministry of Finance, the European Commission announced on October 14, 2015 that it had suspended the reimbursement of some projects until the police investigation was completed. At the same time, it also postponed the decision on the amount that it would not reimburse to the Czech Republic. However, the government immediately decided (.pdf) to reimburse the monitoring system from the state budget. As a result, the state lost approximately 820 million crowns.

The police dropped the investigation into the contract for the monitoring system for European subsidies in early 2019, stating that no crime had occurred. The Commission was made aware of this and consequently applied a 25% correction for errors that occurred in the award of the contract.

In addition to the Czech Police and the European Commission, the Office for the Protection of Competition (ÚOHS) also investigated the IT contract at the Ministry for Regional Development. At the end of 2015, the Antimonopoly Office imposed a fine of 100,000 crowns on the ministry for errors in the contract, but also decided that it did not find evidence of a cartel agreement. The fine was subsequently reduced to 50,000 crowns.

Minister Dostálová is therefore right that the case of the contract for the monitoring system of European funds was examined by the Police of the Czech Republic, the Antimonopoly Office and the European Commission. The Police's conclusions show that no crime was committed. However, it is not true that Lukáš Wagenknecht " scammed " the Czech Republic in Brussels. The European Commission requested the audit, with the knowledge of today's Prime Minister Babiš.

SECTION F:

Minister Dostálová is talking about the government bill (.pdf) amending Act No. 134/2016 Coll. , on public procurement. This bill has been submitted to the Chamber of Deputies as Chamber of Deputies Paper No. 862. By Government Resolution No. 534 (.pdf) of Monday, May 11 (4 days before the interview), the Government requested that this bill be discussed in a shortened session, and the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, Radek Vondráček, granted the request (.pdf).

According to Section 99 of the Act on the Rules of Procedure of the Chamber of Deputies, an abbreviated session in a state of legislative emergency means omitting the first reading of the bill, the possibility of omitting the general debate, and the possibility of limiting the time of individual deputies at the rostrum in the plenary session. It also gives the Speaker of the Chamber the opportunity to order the Guarantee Committee a deadline by which the committee must submit a resolution on the given proposal.

This resolution was issued by the guarantee committee, i.e. the committee for public administration and regional development, at meeting No. 39 (.pdf, invitation) on May 13, 2020 at 10:00. Here, it issued resolution No. 203 (.pdf) on the proposal, in which it proposes to the Chamber of Deputies to hold a general debate, conduct a detailed debate on all parts of the proposal and conclude the discussion on the proposal by 24:00 on the same day, i.e. Wednesday, May 13, 2020. At the same time, it recommends that the PS approve the proposal.

Before the start of the Chamber of Deputies' session on May 13 (which began at 3:00 p.m.), press conferences were held by the parliamentary groups. From the regular order of speeches by the individual parties in the press atrium and the recording of the Czech Television broadcast from that day, we conclude that at the original time of its press conference (2:40 p.m.), the ANO parliamentary group was still deliberating.

At 12:30, Martin Kolovratník, a member of parliament for ANO, uploaded his amendment (.docx) to the proposed amendment to the parliamentary system. At 14:16, member of parliament Pekarová Adamová (TOP 09) uploaded her amendment No. 5248 (.docx) and at about the time of the press conference, i.e. at 14:43, 3 more amendments No. 5251 (.docx), No. 5252 (.docx) and No. 5253 (.docx) from member of parliament Profant (Pirates) were already uploaded to the system. As early as May 12, there was amendment No. 5225 (.docx) from member of parliament Jelínek (SPD). At the time when the ANO parliamentary group was in session, several amendments to the government amendment to the law had already been uploaded to the parliamentary system.

Originally, the agenda of this meeting was to discuss the aforementioned government proposal. Right at the beginning of the meeting, deputies Michálek, Pikal (Pirates), Jurečka (KDU-ČSL) and Okamura (SPD) spoke out against this point. Deputy Faltýnek (chairman of the ANO parliamentary group) responded by announcing that at the meeting of the parliamentary group, after which they did not have time to announce this decision to the media at a press conference, they agreed not to discuss this proposal in a state of legislative emergency (in an abbreviated meeting) and to postpone its regular discussion to the next meeting. At the proposal of deputy Michálek, this point was eliminated by vote no. 3 with the support of 101 out of 107 registered deputies (6 abstained). The next 49th meeting of the PS is scheduled for May 26, 2020, and the first reading of the proposal is tentatively scheduled there as point no. 76.

The gradual recording of amendments could therefore have been one of the reasons why the ANO parliamentary group supported the discussion of the law in the standard procedure.

Respond only with either TRUE or FALSE and the correct section name, examples: TRUE, SECTION A.
